 I agree that the mother's health exception is vaguely worded and that vagueness can be a problem. Right now, it seems like we have a choice of two extremes - either grant the health exception for any health risk or don't grant it at all. Of those two extremes, I would rather err on the side of allowing it and let people's consciences decide. 
 
 As to the idea of trying to narrow down that health risk exception, I had set up a thread specifically for that purpose. I, for one, thought that the health exception should cover severe health risks (ex. of paralysis, severe heart trouble risking an early death, mental health risking suicide, etc.) but not everyday health risks associated with normal pregnancies. It is the gray region in between that is tricky and I had opened that thread to hear people's opinions on it.

 I agree that all other reasonably safe options (such as caesarian delivery, in womb operations, etc.) should be looked into before resorting to abortion in that third trimester. As with the example of the friend of jitobear, sometimes there is just not a reasonably safe option for a particular woman since her conditions might not allow those alternate procedures.
 
 As for the question of limits on the health exception, yes, the exceptions that are clearer to me are the ones that could ultimately lead to the mother's death or complete debilitation. However, there is also a gray region that I am undecided on.
 
 For example:
 - What if the pregnancy would lead to less critical loss - such as the loss of use of her legs or arms? What about one limb - such as the use of one arm?
 - What if the pregnancy would give a medium chance of loss - such as a 20% chance of paralysis?
 
 The gray region is harder to quantify and the moral balance gets trickier. Perhaps that is why this issue hasn't really been addressed specifically in law. Where decisions in morally gray regions are concerned, it is too easy to criticize them and politically unwise to venture into that territory.

 I am a pro-choice proponent who, like many others in this forum and elsewhere, does start recognizing fetal rights to life around the beginning of the third trimester - when some mental existence can first come into being. So, one could even hypothetically call us pro-choice in the first two trimesters and pro-life in the third trimester. We only recognize fetal rights to life in the third trimester whereas you on the pro-life side claim fetal rights to life exist in all trimesters. 
 
 It is interesting to me that, in the consideration of fetal vs woman's rights in that third trimester, we on the pro-choice side and you on the pro-life side start to speak a common language since we take many of the same balances into account. 
 
 I would also think it may be an admirable thing to see someone (a mother in this case) sacrificing herself for her late term, fairly soon to be born fetus but I agree that one cannot force someone by law to sacrifice themselves thus. It has to be their choice. 
 
 As for drawing a line to that health exception, I can imagine that you would be concerned that some women might take the health exception too far in the other direction and claim a health exception since, for example, their metabolism might greatly change and make them fat. I would agree with the fear of such minor health risks being claimed as exceptions for abortion and would hope that the health exception could be worded in such a way as to exclude those. The tricky part is always the morally gray region in between those two extremes. I think that is what makes it so hard to properly word the health exception.
 
As stated by many, the notion of a later term, partial birth abortion is, to me grosteque and vile. 

 I am curious about why you and many others view this procedure as being so much more grotesque and vile than cutting up a fetus inside the womb, or other such procedures that happen inside the womb? Is it because the fetus is exposed to the outside world while it is being killed? Do you think the fetus suffers more? (On that last point, my understanding is that anesthesia is used in late term abortions to keep the fetus from suffering, but I might be wrong). In essence, my question is: what makes this particular procedure stand out so much as being very bad?

Well first, let's remember that SCOTUS was not making a value judgment on abortion--they were ruling on the constitutionality of this particular law. As Justice Kennedy stated, the opponents of the act "have not demonstrated that the Act would be unconstitutional in a large fraction of relevant cases."

 So, the constitutionality of an issue depends on the percentage of people whose constitutional rights get violated by a law? What about the constitutional rights of the minority whose health risk would require that particular procedure to be used? I am certainly not an expert in constitutional jurisprudence, but the actions of this version of SCOTUS smacks of the legislating from the bench that Republicans have criticized Democrats for. I think that there is room for interpretation in the Constitution that can swing things one way or the other, but I think that the constitutional rights of ALL people need to be considered when addressing a particular law - not just of the majority. 
 
Now if you want to discuss why that law has support among people, I think the key here is that this procedure is a late-term form of abortion. So it's not just the gruesomeness of it, but the fact it is performed so late in the pregnancy. That is the basis, I believe, that helped more than anything in public support for this law. Does that mean that all late-term abortions should be banned (sans exceptions)? Well, yes I would like to see that happen. As you point out, a lot of pro-choicers might like to see that happen as well.

 My understanding (from a pro-life site no less) is that most such procedures are done in the fifth and sixth month of pregnancy - i.e. mostly the second trimester not the third. Since 84% of people support making third trimester abortions generally illegal and 68% of people support making second trimester abortions generally illegal, I can see how a mainly second trimester procedure would have gotten the support of enough people on the pro-choice side to swing the balance. Judging from those poll numbers, the majority of pro-choice supporters, including myself, would keep second trimester abortions generally legal. I, personally, would only support a general ban on this procedure only around the third trimester (or close to that) on and, as we had already discussed, I would include the health exception - which this law does not include.
 
 All that being said, if outlawing late-term abortions was the main goal of the law, why was that not addressed directly? My concern is that this is a somewhat underhanded approach of outlawing a procedure because of nebulous criteria such as gruesomeness, where such nebulous criteria could be applied to other abortion procedures to ultimately get rid of all of them - i.e. the slippery slope.
 
 On a related issue, one criticism of this procedure is that it could be very painful for the fetus being aborted. I had originally thought that any abortions that are performed late enough for the fetus to have developed a sense of pain would be done with fetal anesthesia (or something of similar function) being applied. From google searching, I have discovered that there is no such requirement. Indeed, it is of great concern to me that there could be very late term abortions performed without such fetal anesthesia. There is an Unborn Child Pain Awareness Act (2005 version), that passed the house last December that requires a woman potentially undergoing a late term abortion to be notified about the pain that the fetus might experience and about the fetal anesthesia option. I would go even further to require fetal anesthesia once it is clear that the fetus can feel pain (except when such anesthesia could pose a great risk to the mother). Most medical studies have ascertained that pain cannot be experienced before 26 weeks gestation. Legislation related to fetal pain has only been introduced in the last several years.
 
 Either way, if it is fetal pain in the partial birth abortion procedure that is the main concern - a concern that I would agree with - then that should be addressed directly with legislation. This is from the AMA and is a policy as identified on their website:
 
 
H-5.982 Late-Term Pregnancy Termination Techniques 
 
 
 (1) The term 'partial birth abortion' is not a medical term. The AMA will use the term "intact dilatation and extraction"(or intact D&X) to refer to a specific procedure comprised of the following elements: deliberate dilatation of the cervix, usually over a sequence of days; instrumental or manual conversion of the fetus to a footling breech; breech extraction of the body excepting the head; and partial evacuation of the intracranial contents of the fetus to effect vaginal delivery of a dead but otherwise intact fetus. This procedure is distinct from dilatation and evacuation (D&E) procedures more commonly used to induce abortion after the first trimester. Because 'partial birth abortion' is not a medical term it will not be used by the AMA. 
 
 (2) According to the scientific literature, there does not appear to be any identified situation in which intact D&X is the only appropriate procedure to induce abortion, and ethical concerns have been raised about intact D&X. The AMA recommends that the procedure not be used unless alternative procedures pose materially greater risk to the woman. The physician must, however, retain the discretion to make that judgment, acting within standards of good medical practice and in the best interest of the patient. 
 
 (3) The viability of the fetus and the time when viability is achieved may vary with each pregnancy. In the second-trimester when viability may be in question, it is the physician who should determine the viability of a specific fetus, using the latest available diagnostic technology. 
 
 (4) In recognition of the constitutional principles regarding the right to an abortion articulated by the Supreme Court in Roe v. Wade, and in keeping with the science and values of medicine, the AMA recommends that abortions not be performed in the third trimester except in cases of serious fetal anomalies incompatible with life. Although third-trimester abortions can be performed to preserve the life or health of the mother, they are, in fact, generally not necessary for those purposes. Except in extraordinary circumstances, maternal health factors which demand termination of the pregnancy can be accommodated without sacrifice of the fetus, and the near certainty of the independent viability of the fetus argues for ending the pregnancy by appropriate delivery. 
 
 (5) The AMA urges the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention as well as state health department officials to develop expanded, ongoing data surveillance systems of induced abortion. This would include but not be limited to: a more detailed breakdown of the prevalence of abortion by gestational age as well as the type of procedure used to induce abortion at each gestational age, and maternal and fetal indications for the procedure. Abortion-related maternal morbidity and mortality statistics should include reports on the type and severity of both short- and long-term complications, type of procedure, gestational age, maternal age, and type of facility. Data collection procedures should ensure the anonymity of the physician, the facility, and the patient. 
 
 (6) The AMA will work with appropriate medical specialty societies, government agencies, private foundations, and other interested groups to educate the public regarding pregnancy prevention strategies, with special attention to at-risk populations, which would minimize or preclude the need for abortions. The demand for abortions, with the exception of those indicated by serious fetal anomalies or conditions which threaten the life or health of the pregnant woman, represent failures in the social environment, education, and contraceptive methods. (BOT Rep. 26, A-97)
